theory_assignments.reasoning: Focuses on accumulation of age-specific deleterious germline mutations due to declining natural selection with age, affecting life-history traits.
Emphasizes accumulation of late-acting deleterious mutations in germline causing increased genetic variance and senescence.
Describes decline in natural selection with age allowing late-acting deleterious germline mutations to accumulate, increasing genetic variance.
Details mutation-selection equilibrium and accumulation of late-acting deleterious germline mutations with minor effects on fitness-relevant ages.
Focuses on accumulation of late-acting deleterious germline mutations with declining selection pressure and modifier genes delaying expression.
Mathematical modeling of age-specific deleterious germline mutations accumulating due to weakened natural selection with age.
Extends classical mutation accumulation with nonlinear demographic interactions and age-specific natural selection decline on germline mutations.
Describes delayed expression of deleterious germline genes and declining natural selection with age causing accumulation and senescence.
Focuses on age-specific accumulation of deleterious germline mutations and increasing inbreeding load with age due to weaker selection.
Models aging as genetic accumulation of deleterious germline mutations influenced by sexual reproduction and weaker late-life selection.
Combines mutation accumulation and antagonistic pleiotropy theories focusing on genetic variance increase with age due to germline mutations.
Modified mutation accumulation allowing alleles with effects spanning neighboring ages, explaining late-life mortality plateaus from germline mutations.
Focuses on accumulation of point mutations in somatic cells due to intrinsic mutagenesis causing aging.
Proposes somatic mutations accumulate progressively with age causing cellular dysfunction and aging phenotypes.
Emphasizes balance between DNA damage and repair in somatic cells, with mutation accumulation driving aging.
Describes accumulation of various somatic mutation types with age and uses transgenic mouse models to study mutation load.
Highlights stochastic accumulation of somatic mutations influenced by genetics and environment as a cause of aging.
Links somatic mutation accumulation to genetic instability underlying both aging and cancer development.
Focuses on trade-offs between reproduction and somatic maintenance shaped by extrinsic mortality influencing aging rate.
Describes evolution of intrinsic mortality and lifespan as a balance between reproduction and survival under extrinsic mortality.
Frames aging as evolutionary neglect with trade-offs favoring early-life fitness at expense of late-life maintenance, including oxidative stress.
Views aging as a transitory phase due to declining natural selection and resource allocation trade-offs between reproduction and maintenance.
Explains senescence as adaptive trade-off with reduced immune investment under high extrinsic mortality environments.
Applies life-history trade-offs to human development, showing resource allocation shifts under low maternal capital affecting aging.
